newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan moves forward digital broadcasts schedule.
newsitem.headline: Japan moves forward digital broadcasts schedule.

text.p: Japan aims to start digitalised terrestrial broadcasting before 2000 by moving forward the original schedule by several years, a Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications official said on Monday.
Japan had originally set a target for the start of such broadcasts of sometime between 2000 and 2005.
But fast development in digital broadcasting technology as well as moves by U.S. and European broadcasters prompted the government to move forward the schedule, the official said.
The ministry hopes to decide on a government-prescribed standard for advanced digital TV, which offers cinema-quality pictures and CD-quality sound, by the summer of 1998, he said.
Test broadcasting will start in the autumn of 1998.
A shift into digital broadcasting from the current analogue system at terrestrial TV stations means consumers will need to replace their TV sets or buy adaptors to see digital programmes.
TV stations will also have to replace nearly all their production and transmission equipment in the coming years so they can broadcast the new programming.
Japan recently decided to employ digital technology for satellite broadcasting from around 2000.
Britain plans to launch digital terrestrial broadcasting early in 1998. The United States also plans to start the service around 1998.
